Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a TXRF spectrometer for Research in Chemistry, Biology, and Geology
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Roger Rowlett from Colgate University and colleagues Richard April, Catherine Cardelus and Randall Fuller will acquire a TXRF (total reflection X-ray fluorescence) spectrometer. In general, in a TXRF spectrometer, X-rays are directed to the surface of a material in a process that excites atoms in the top layers thus generating fluorescence. The measurement of the fluorescence in a detector provides information on the material composition. The technique is very sensitive and allows quantification of minute amounts of materials with minimal sample manipulation allowing characterization of complex, heterogeneous matrices. The instrumentation will be used in research and inquire-based laboratories not only in Chemistry but also in Biology and Geology.

The award will enhance research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) investigatiion of beta-carbonic anhy drase (beta-CA) to understand the mechanism of allosteric regulation in this enzyme; (b) understanding the effects of acidic deposition on northeastern deciduous forests of the United States; and (c) studying aluminum toxicity in acid-stressed stream ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research grant supported the acquisition of a Total Reflectance X-ray Fluorescence (TXRF) spectrometer to facilitate the quantitative elemental analysis of biological and environmental samples a low volume or in trace quantities. Principal research outcomes include: (1) the development and validation of methodology for identifying and quantifying metals in metalloproteins; TXRF was found to be a superior method for this task compared to atomic spectroscopy or other analytical methods, especially for low volume samples or complex mixtures; (2) the accurate identification and measurement of heavy metal contamination in soil and vegetation near a mine project near Ogdensburg, NJ., where significant quantities of zinc, barium, lead, copper, and nickel were found; plant materials near the mine exhibited high levels of zinc, iron, and manganese; (3) TXRF he measurements of calcium and manganese in limed Adirondack soils provided valuable information about the mobility of these elements soil and plant biosphere, including an apparent loss of bioavaibililty of manganese, an important plant nutrient, in limed soils.

Broader impacts include the implementation of an inquiry-based instructional laboratory in a foundational analytical chemistry course, in which students pose and answer scientifically interesting questions concerning elemental composition or contamination of foods, drinking water, cosmetics or other common encountered consumer products. In addition, the research projects described above all involved undergraduate researchers, who gained valuable experience conducting authentic science research and dissemination. The TXRF instrument has added significant trace element identification and quantification capability to the institutional analytical chemistry instrumentation holdings.
